title: 107_s22
content:
The Act titled "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for disclosure, limits on soft money of national political party committees, and miscellaneous provisions. It mandates additional disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, increased electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, software for filing reports, limits on soft money, judicial review, and an increase in contribution limits. Title I of the "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for disclosure, penalties update, and filing Senate reports with the Federal Election Commission. It also mandates additional monthly and quarterly disclosure reports. The Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001 mandates additional monthly and quarterly disclosure reports for Principal Campaign Committees. Monthly reports are due by the 20th day after the last day of the month, except for November and December, with a year-end report due by January 31 of the following year. The Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001 requires quarterly reports to be filed by the treasurer not later than the 15th day after the end of each quarter, with the exception of the report for the quarter ending December 31, which must be filed by January 31 of the following year. Additionally, a national committee of a political party must file the reports required under subparagraph (B). Conforming amendments are made to Section 304(a) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require monthly reports instead of quarterly reports. Section 309(b) is also amended to replace "calendar quarter" with "month". SEC. 102. REPORTING BY NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national and congressional political committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period. Political committees must separately itemize reporting for any person with receipts or disbursements exceeding $200 in a calendar year. Reports required to be filed under this subsection shall be filed for the same time periods required for political committees under subsection (a). SEC. 103. INCREASED ELECTRONIC DISCLOSURE. The Commission will make reports available online and at their offices within 24 hours of receiving the information. SEC. 104. PUBLIC ACCESS TO BROADCASTING RECORDS. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require licensees to maintain and make available for public inspection a complete record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. Licensees must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters, including acceptance/rejection, rates, air date/time, class of time, candidate's name and office sought, election or issue referenced. Licensees must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters, including details of the requester and information about the candidate or person purchasing the time. This information must be placed in a political file promptly and retained for at least 2 years. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 has been amended to require the development and provision of software for filing reports at no cost to individuals required to file. The software must be used by those maintaining or filing reports under the Act. SEC. 324 of Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 imposes limits on soft money contributions of national political party committees. SEC. 324 of Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 imposes limits on soft money contributions of national political party committees. A national committee, congressional campaign committee, or related entity cannot accept donations exceeding $60,000 from a person in a calendar year. Individuals are also restricted from making disbursements over $60,000 in a year, with adjustments based on the price index after 2001. The increase in contribution limits under SEC. 324 is tied to the price index determined in 2001, with adjustments made annually. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Any Member of Congress, candidate, national committee of a political party, or any person affected by section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 can bring a legal action in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia to challenge the constitutionality of the section. Any order from the District Court can be appealed directly to the Supreme Court of the United States within specific time frames. The jurisdictional statement must be filed within 30 days of the order. The District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court must expedite the disposition of cases under subsection (a). Enforcement of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act is stayed until the final disposition by the Supreme Court. This section applies to actions filed within 30 days under subsection (a). Actions filed under subsection (a) must be submitted within 30 days of the effective date of this Act. SEC. 203: Increase in contribution limits. Increase in contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, with individual and political committee limits raised to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000 respectively. Multicandidate limits also increased to $75,000. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. Limits are raised to $7,500 for individuals, $30,000 for political committees, and $15,000 for national party committees. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. Limits are raised to $7,500 for individuals, $30,000 for political committees, and $15,000 for national party committees. Amendments include adjustments to limitations in calendar years after 2002, with specific provisions for subsections (a) and (h) for a 2-year period. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. Limits are raised to $7,500 for individuals, $30,000 for political committees, and $15,000 for national party committees. Amendments include adjustments to limitations in calendar years after 2002, with specific provisions for subsections (a) and (h) for a 2-year period. Additionally, Senate candidate contribution limits for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees are increased from $17,500 to $60,000. Effective dates for these amendments apply to calendar years beginning after December 31, 2001. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees, with adjustments for calendar years after 2002. Effective dates for these changes apply to calendar years after December 31, 2001. TITLE III--MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

SEC. 301. PROHIBITION OF SOLICITATION OF POLITICAL PARTY SOFT MONEY IN FEDERAL BUILDINGS. Section 607 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to define "contribution" as a gift, subscription, loan, advance, or deposit of money made in connection with elections for Federal office or political committees. Section 602(a)(4) of title 18 is also amended to include a prohibition of donations. The text chunk amends section 607 of title 18, United States Code, by defining "contribution" as a gift, subscription, loan, advance, or deposit of money in connection with elections. It also prohibits donations in section 602(a)(4) of title 18. SEC. 302 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to adjust penalty amounts for inflation based on the price index. This adjustment applies to calendar years after 2001. SEC. 303 requires Senate reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. SEC. 303 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require all designations, statements, and reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. Conforming amendments are made to various sections to reflect this change.
